13.05.text: Then it became a hotel and that was when I first visited

17.80.text: with my husband and was absolutely bowled over with the history,

28.00.text: a very special place for us to come,  but also to bring friends and family.

38.00.text: People who come who are on their own,

41.70.text:
and it actually makes such a difference
to their lives.

45.00.text: Two thousand acres in the heart of the Vale of Aylesbury.

51.80.text: Hartwell was always intended to be one of the great gardens of England.

57.33.text:
tranquility and solitude to escape from
the busy world.

62.89.text: So here we are at the end of Hartwells' lake.

68.00.text: in this most tranquil of estates.

71.60.text: And HS2 will be coming down behind the

74.79.text: rifle spinney here and behind this belt of trees at the end of the lake,

80.00.text:
before it disappears off up towards
Waddesdon and to the north.

84.00.text: Here we are now on the north side of the house.

86.80.text: The entrance front.  And we've got the lake on our left,

91.00.text: and then we've got the house with the entrance.

95.10.text: and the oriel window looking straight up this avenue.

99.40.text: will cut across just this side of that hedge on the horizon.

105.00.text: Hartwell House and parkland have played an important role in the history of both

109.54.text:
the local area and the country for the
last thousand years.

113.80.text: With the care and dedication of the National Trust and your help

116.80.text: we can preserve this unique treasure for future generations to come.
